title: Enterocutaneous Fistula
diagnosis_topic: Abnormal connection between intestinal lumen and skin surface
setup_script: A 55-year-old woman develops a draining wound on her abdomen 10 days after a complicated bowel resection for Crohn's disease. The output is high volume and appears like intestinal contents.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 110/70 mmHg, HR 105 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 38 C.
Effluent of 800 mL/day of bilious fluid from midline incision; surrounding skin excoriated and erythematous.
Albumin low at 2.0 g/dL, electrolyte imbalances (low potassium, magnesium), WBC 14 K/uL.
High output >500 mL/day; determines that sepsis is present due to fever and leukocytosis.
Broad-spectrum antibiotics started, blood cultures drawn and source control achieved with drainage of intra-abdominal abscess if present (CT-guided drainage).
NPO, nasogastric decompression and initiation of total parenteral nutrition; consider octreotide to reduce secretion though evidence mixed.
Apply stoma appliance or wound manager with barrier creams to prevent excoriation; coordinate with enterostomal therapy nurse.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for distal obstruction
dynamic_flow.reply: CT enterography performed to assess for distal obstruction or ongoing disease.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If fistula fails to close after 3-6 months of optimized nutrition and control
dynamic_flow.reply: Plan for elective surgical resection and anastomosis once inflammation resolved.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident rushes to early surgery
dynamic_flow.reply: High failure and recurrence due to inflamed tissue and malnutrition.
Discuss emotional impact and involve social work and nutrition services.
Importance of adherence to nutritional plan, skin care and signs of complications like sepsis or electrolyte derangements.

critical_decision_points: Assessment of fistula output, sepsis and nutritional status
Sepsis control and source identification with imaging and drainage
Optimization of nutrition and fistula management to promote spontaneous closure
Timing of definitive surgery only after optimization and absence of infection
Comprehensive wound care and psychosocial support for patient
